content.question: Identical spheres are dropped from a height of <math alttext="100 meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>100</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> above the surfaces of Planet <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and Planet <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The speed of the spheres as a function of time is recorded for each planet in the graph above. Which planet exerts the greater force of gravity on the sphere, and what evidence supports this conclusion?

choices.label: Planet <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because its line has the greater area under it.
Planet <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because its line has the greater slope.
Planet <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it falls for the smaller amount of time.
Planet <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the object’s final speed is greater.

content.answer: Planet <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because its line has the greater slope.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
